results.title: Hunting the wild pineapple
results.creator_credit: Patricia L'Huede, Don Colantonio and AFTRS
results.brief_description: A film in search of Thea Astley through stories, anecdotes and a little bit of gossip. Australian writer, Thea Astley, holds forth on her attitudes to writing, rednecks, satire, sex, being a woman, inspiration, God and her spiritual home - the cafeteria. “Hunting the Wild Pineapple” blends excerpts of interviews with Astley and dramatised extracts from her writings.

results.title: Hunting Ground (Haunted) Van Diemen's Land
results.brief_description: HUNTING GROUND (Haunted) Van Diemen’s Land is a video artwork by Julie Gough.

constellations_other.name: Black documentary and truth telling
constellations_other.description: Essie Coffey was a trailblazer of Indigenous filmmaking, being the first Aboriginal woman to direct a documentary. The film spotlights the outspoken voice Coffey utilised to convey the realities faced by Aboriginal people and to encourage resistance to assimilation.

results.description: HUNTING GROUND (Haunted) Van Diemen’s Land is a video artwork by Julie Gough.
description_for_label: HUNTING GROUND (Haunted) Van Diemen’s Land is a video artwork by Julie Gough.

results.title: Hunters of the Skies the Falcons
results.brief_description: This informative documentary looks at the six species of falcons found in Australia. Dramatic high-speed camera sequences capture the power and speed of the falcons in flight and during hunting. Despite their speed and power, survival for young falcons is still not an easy task. Approximately 70% of the young birds do not survive their first year.

results.title: Hungry minds
results.brief_description: A documentary report of the intellectual starvation in countries ravaged by WWII. Schools are now lost in the rubble with homes, hospitals and churches; children gather knowledge of the world from the black markets and the refuse dumps, roving in gangs through the litter of civilisation. From mute faces, eyes stare hungrily, marking the desolation war has wrought in minds as well as bodies. It is here that a beginning must be made: textbooks, writing materials, research equipment, and a thousand other tools of knowledge are needed to break apathy and hostility, and to open young minds to the promise of a peaceful world.

results.title: Hunger = La Faim
results.creator_credit: Peter Foldes, Rene Jordan and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: Computer animated satire of self-indulgence in a hungry world. Rapidly dissolving, reshaping images, made with the aid of a computer, create a stark contrast between abundance and want. A man eats, at first sparingly, but his appetite grows to gluttony, greed, and gratification of every desire. The nightmare that finally haunts him is the one that hangs over our disparate world. A film without words. Animation, Nestor Burtnyk, Marceli Wein and Peter Foldes. Music, Pierre F. Brault. Editing, Pierre Lemelin.

results.title: Humphrey Jennings Compilation
results.brief_description: A compilation of works by Humphrey Jennings. “Fires Were Started”: Jenning’s only semi-documentary feature about a waterfront fire service station during the blitz in London. “Listen to Britain”: production of the sights and sounds of people at war, without commentary. “Words for Battle”: spoken. “True story of Lili Marlene”: dramatic reconstruction of the British counter-propaganda campaign against the popular German forces programme from Belgrade Radio.

results.title: Human nature (2001)
results.creator_credit: Michel Gondry, Anthony Bregman, Charlie Kaufman, Spike Jonze, Ted Hope, Fineline Features and Studio Canal
results.brief_description: Feature film debut for video filmmaker Michel Gondry and follow-up for writer Charlie Kaufman of “Being John Malkovich” fame. A quirky love triangle about dysfunctional people all wanting acceptance, or is it just sex they are after? Lila (Patricia Arquette) is covered in body hair and loves the solitary life of the wild-outdoors but her sexual needs take her to the city. After some intensive hair removal by an electrolysis expert (Rosie Perez), Lila finds love with scientist Nathan (Tim Robbins) who experiments on mice, teaching them table manners. Together they find a wild man (Rhys Ifans) who was raised by apes, whom Nathan and his lusty French assistant (Miranda Otto) name “Puff”. After Nathan’s taming and re-training of Puff, Lila wants to free Puff from the laboratory allowing him return to his true nature.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Michel Gondry, Anthony Bregman, Charlie Kaufman, Spike Jonze, Ted Hope, Fineline Features and Studio Canal

results.title: Human instinct. Ep. 4. Natural born heroes
results.creator_credit: Samantha Starbuck, BBC and TLC Films
results.brief_description: Robert Winston presents this series that looks into what it means to be human: the instincts we have and why we behave the way we do. Humans have a natural instinct to help others, and, by extension, we are programmed to love and protect our children from birth. It all begins with a mother’s drive to protect her young, facilitated by a chemical reaction. The same experience occurs for men. With birth comes the transference of genetic material, especially in animals, and experiments are underway to see whether the same rule applies to humans, who will do more for those that they share the most genes with. The instinct to help others, particularly those who are more vulnerable extends beyond the family, to friends and complete strangers, and examples are provided from a soldier in the Vietnam War and survivors of the World Trade Centre bombing. Wanting to help others is related to our instinct to empathise, a phenomenon that Professor Robert Winston illustrated graphically through scientific experimentation. Our instinct to communicate with others is also covered.
